Review: Waited two years on a waiting list and ended up with the F-350 Lariat with the 6.7L Power Stroke Diesel. Original order was for a Limited Edition, and when we were told the features would be delayed due to manufacturing issues, we changed to the combination above. Was completely blown away at the ride and handling versus our previous heavy-duty truck. Still love that truck, but the F-350 is so much more refined for both on and off-road use. The spaciousness of the cabin versus the other truck was a great surprise as well. Had the typical first year production gremlins that I've experienced in Asian, German, and American vehicles we were early adopters of; comes with the territory and Ford stayed in touch and took care of them as they came up. Never driven anything outside of a military HUMMV that was this confidence-inspiring off-road, towing heavy loads with ease, I mean at the turn of a dial all the towing modes did what was asked of them. Interior noise shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who's owned a heavy-duty truck. Interior materials and drain holes for rinsing out dirt and debris were great. I would love it if Ford made a solid one-piece body like the Ram. No regrets at all. *Edmunds doesn't have the Lariat with the 6.7L Diesel, but that was our combination so maybe they can fix that.

Review: Waited two years on a waiting list and ended up with the Grand Cherokee L with the 5.7L V8. Originally ordered a different trim but when we learned about some delays, we switched to this combination. I was completely blown away by the ride and handling compared to our previous SUV. Still love our old vehicle, but the Grand Cherokee L is so much more refined for both on and off-road use. The spaciousness of the interior and the comfort of the seating was a great surprise as well. Had the typical first year production gremlins that I've experienced in various vehicles we've owned; comes with the territory, but Jeep stayed in touch and took care of them as they arose. I've never driven anything outside of a military HUMMV that was this confidence-inspiring off-road, in the water, or while towing; the various terrain modes did exactly what was needed with just a turn of a dial. Interior noise shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who's owned an SUV with a panoramic roof. The interior materials and the thoughtful design for easy cleaning were impressive. I would love it if Jeep made a solid one-piece body like some luxury brands. No regrets at all.

Review: Waited two years on a waiting list and ended up with the Highlander XSE with the 3.5L V6. Originally ordered a Limited trim, but when we were informed that some features would not be available due to manufacturing issues, we switched to the combination above. Was completely blown away at the ride and handling compared to our previous SUV. Still love our old vehicle, but the Highlander is so much more refined for both on and off-road use. The spaciousness of the cabin versus our previous SUV was a great surprise as well. Had the typical first year production quirks that I've experienced in various vehicles we've owned; comes with the territory, and Toyota stayed in touch and took care of them as they came up. Never driven anything outside of a military HUMMV that was this confidence-inspiring off-road, in the water, or when launching jet skis with no boat ramp; at the turn of a dial, all the drive modes performed flawlessly. Interior noise shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who's owned an SUV with a soft top. The interior materials and drainage solutions for rinsing out sand and mud were excellent. I would love it if Toyota made a solid one-piece body like the Land Rover. No regrets at all.

Review: Waited two years on a waiting list and ended up with the Outer Banks and 2.7 with Soft Top. Original Order was for a First Edition and when we were told the Top would not be molded in color due to manufacturing issues, we changed from the limited production First Edition to the combination above. Was completely blown away at the ride and handling versus our Wrangler. Still love the Wrangler, but the Bronco is so much more refined from both on and off road use. The openness of the roll cage versus the Wrangler was a great surprise as well. Had the typical first year production gremlins that I've experienced in Asian, German, and American vehicles we were early adopters of; comes with the territory and Ford stayed in touch and took care of them as they came up. Never driven anything outside of a military HUMMV that was this confidence inspiring off road, in the water, launching jet skis with no boat ramp, I mean at the turn of a dial all the off road modes did what was asked of them. Interior Noise shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who's owned a soft top Jeep. Interior material and drain holes for rinsing the sand and mud out were great. I would love it if Ford made a Solid one piece body like the Land Rover. No regrets at all. *Edmunds doesn't have Outer Banks with the 2.7 4door, but that was our combination so maybe they can fix that.

Review: Needed a new truck. I had no intention of buying a heavy-duty vehicle, let alone a Chevrolet. My wife wanted to check out trucks, so I reluctantly agreed. First, we drove some lighter models. Meh. Then she showed me the specs of a Silverado 3500, and I agreed to test drive it. 1. You schedule test drive via online. We found it super convenient. Knew exactly when and where we would be test driving, no waiting in the lot for some pushy salesman. 2. Sign in, Chevrolet rep greets us and lets us look around, then explains to us how to use the features. No sales pushing, just answering all our questions. 3. Supposed to be a 30 min test drive, we couldn't stop, went for an hour. It was thought changing. I went from being a truck skeptic to a Chevrolet enthusiast in 60 min. 4. Went online and bought a truck that afternoon. Again, no scumbag slimy salesman, everything straightforward and easy. 5. Did have to download the app to finish the process to fill out the paperwork. But, this was fine, do it from the living room couch rather than in a crazy office with some sales idiot bugging you to buy some stupid extras. 6. The only hiccup, app prompts you to pay before picking up the truck. I just messaged in the app that I preferred to see the truck before paying. Response, No problem. 7. Pickup fast, efficient, trouble-free. People were great. The whole experience left us thinking, this all works together so well. Everything is well thought out and customer experience well thought out. Truck is just a pleasure to drive. Fun, powerful, quiet, and handles well. Relaxing to drive in traffic. With tax credits, cheaper than a standard pickup. We did get a home charger for the electric version, makes the ownership sooo much better. Just plug it in every night and never worry about range for normal commuting. Day three, first day commuting, we got a weird rock ding and broke the front passenger window. Got home. Called service (they answered fast) and they recommended using the app to schedule service. (They offered to schedule over the phone, but I wanted to try the app). Tried it, flawless to schedule service. Asked you to describe the problem, take some pics and submit. Within minutes, got a message that a mobile appointment was scheduled. App asked for insurance, and that was it. Tech showed up in service time. Fixed the window fast, answered a bunch of questions we had about features, and then was off. No muss, no fuss. Mobile service was AWESOME! Oh, total cost to us was $0. Fit and finish great. Driving in rain great. 500-mile road trip with family of four great. Total cost, $16. Time at charging station, 14 min from 30% to 95%. People complain about no CarPlay/Android Auto, non-issue. Chevrolet navigation is outstanding. Phone Bluetooth connects for calls. Connectivity lets you connect to streaming services you subscribe to. Don't care about CarPlay/Android Auto anymore, it's irrelevant. You do have to take some time to learn how to use everything but it's time well spent as there's sooo much there for you to tailor the truck to how you want things. Chevrolet Silverado 3500. Two months, 2000 miles. Loving it. Can't wait for our other vehicle to have an issue, so we can justify getting another Silverado.

Called service (they answered fast) and they recommended using the app to schedule service. (They offered to schedule over the phone, but I wanted to try the app). Tried it, flawless to schedule service. Asked you to describe the problem, take some pics, and submit. Within minutes, got a message that a mobile appointment was scheduled. App asked for insurance, and that was it. Tech showed up in service time. Fixed the window fast, answered a bunch of questions we had about features, and then was off. No muss, no fuss. Mobile service was AWESOME! Oh, total cost to us was $0. Fit and finish great. Driving in rain great. 500-mile road trip with a family of four great. Total cost, $16. Time at charging station, 14 min from 30% to 95%. People complain about no advanced tech features, non-issue. GMC navigation is outstanding. Phone Bluetooth connects for calls. Connectivity lets you connect to streaming services you subscribe to. Don't care about advanced tech features anymore, it's irrelevant. You do have to take some time to learn how to use everything but it's time well spent as there's sooo much there for you to tailor the truck to how you want things. GMC Sierra 2500HD. Two months, 2000 miles. Loving it. Can't wait for our other vehicle to have an issue, so we can justify getting a Sierra 1500.

Review: Needed a new car. I had no intention of buying a sports coupe, let alone a Ford Mustang. My wife wanted to check out some performance vehicles, so I reluctantly agreed. First, we drove some other coupes. Meh. Then she showed me the price of a Mustang and I agreed to test drive it. 1. You schedule a test drive online. We found it super convenient. Knew exactly when and where we would be test driving, no waiting in a car lot for some pushy salesman. 2. Sign in, Ford rep greets us and lets us look around, then explains to us how to use the features. No sales pushing, just answering all our questions. 3. Supposed to be a 30 min test drive, we couldn't stop, went for an hour. It was thought changing. I went from being a sports car skeptic to a Mustang enthusiast in 60 min. 4. Went online and bought a car that afternoon. Again, no scumbag slimy car salesman, everything straightforward and easy. 5. Did have to download the app to finish the process to fill out the paperwork. But, this was fine, do it from the living room couch rather than in a crazy office with some sales idiot bugging you to buy some stupid extras. 6. The only hiccup, app prompts you to pay before picking up the car. I just messaged in the app that I preferred to see the car before paying. Response, No problem. 7. Pickup was fast, efficient, and trouble-free. People were great. The whole experience left us thinking, this all works together so well. Everything is well thought out and customer experience is well considered. The car is just a pleasure to drive. Fun, fast, quiet, handles well. Relaxing to drive in traffic. With tax credits, cheaper than a standard sedan. We did get a home charger, makes the ownership sooo much better. Just plug it in every night and never worry about range for normal commuting. Day three, first day commuting, we got a weird rock ding and broke the front passenger door window. Got home. Called service (they answered fast) and they recommended using the app to schedule service. (They offered to schedule over the phone, but I wanted to try the app). Tried it, flawless to schedule service. Asked you to describe the problem, take some pics and submit. Within minutes, got a message that a mobile appointment was scheduled. App asked for insurance, and that was it. Tech showed up in service time. Fixed the window fast, answered a bunch of questions we had about features and then was off. No muss, no fuss. Mobile service was AWESOME! Oh, total cost to us was $0. Fit and finish great. Driving in rain great. 500-mile road trip with family of four great. Total cost, $16. Time at charging station, 14 min from 30% to 95%. People complain about no CarPlay/Android Auto, non-issue. Ford navigation is outstanding. Phone Bluetooth connects for calls. Connectivity lets you connect to streaming services you subscribe to. Don't care about CarPlay/Android Auto anymore, it's irrelevant. You do have to take some time to learn how to use everything but it's time well spent as there's sooo much there for you to tailor the car to how you want things. Ford Mustang GT. Two months, 2000 miles. Loving it. Can't wait for our other car to have an issue, so we can justify getting a Mustang convertible.

Review: I purchased the Chevrolet Colorado single cab with an extended bed, & the 2.7 liter 6 cylinder. Everything was great. I bought the truck because my previous vehicle was getting a lot of miles & having issues. Needed something reliable. On my way home from work, I stopped at the grocery store, when I was ready to leave, I turn the key & it wouldn't start or even crank up at all. My display was showing multiple faults like brakes, camera, blind spot lights, among many other faults. The brake lights came on and wouldn't shut off until the battery went completely dead. It was 7pm. I went to the Chevrolet app & ordered a tow truck which did not arrive. By 1am I tried calling the tow truck company & they never answered. I called AAA which I should have done to begin with & even they didn't show up until 6am. I sat in my truck for 11 hrs in the grocery store parking lot totally stranded. By 8am I called the Chevrolet dealer to get a tow truck to my house & was furious by that point. A tow truck arrived a couple hours later to take the truck to the dealer I bought it from. The dealer tells me there's 35 vehicles ahead of me waiting for service & it will be a while before they could even look at my truck. It's been 5 days & they still haven't looked at it. The day I bought the truck the sales person told me I wouldn't have any problems but if I did, they would take care of me immediately. So glad I didn't trade in my previous vehicle because I'm self-employed & would be losing a lot of money and business. I bought my 2024 Colorado just 6 weeks ago and it's already broke down and unusable! Here I am paying for a brand new truck I can't even use! Wishing now that I never would have bought it!! Total let down!!

Review: I purchased the Tesla Model 3 with the standard battery and all-wheel drive. Everything was great initially. I bought the car because my old sedan was getting a lot of miles and having issues. I needed something reliable. On my way home from work, I stopped at the grocery store, and when I was ready to leave, I tapped the screen to start the car, but it wouldn't respond at all. My display was showing multiple faults like brakes, autopilot, and battery alerts, among many other issues. The brake lights came on and wouldn't shut off until the battery completely drained. It was 7pm. I went to the Tesla app and ordered a tow truck, which did not arrive. By 1am I tried calling the tow truck company and they never answered. I called AAA, which I should have done to begin with, and even they didn't show up until 6am. I sat in my car for 11 hours in the grocery store parking lot, totally stranded. By 8am I called the Tesla service center to get a tow truck to my house and was furious by that point. A tow truck arrived a couple of hours later to take the car to the dealer I bought it from. The dealer tells me there's 35 vehicles ahead of me waiting for service and it will be a while before they can even look at my car. It's been 5 days and they still haven't looked at it. The day I bought the car, the salesperson assured me I wouldn't have any problems, but if I did, they would take care of me immediately. I'm so glad I didn't trade in my old sedan because I'm self-employed and would be losing a lot of money and business. I bought my 2024 Model 3 just 6 weeks ago and it's already broken down and unusable! Here I am paying for a brand new car I can't even use! Wishing now that I never would have bought it!! Total let down!!

Review: I purchased the Ram 1500 Crew Cab with the 3.6-liter V6. Everything started off great. I bought the truck because my previous vehicle was getting a lot of miles and having issues. Needed something reliable. On my way home from work, I stopped at the grocery store, and when I was ready to leave, I turned the key, and it wouldn't start or even crank at all. My display was showing multiple faults like brakes, camera, blind spot lights, among many other faults. The brake lights came on and wouldn't shut off until the battery went completely dead. It was 7pm. I went to the Ram app and ordered a tow truck, which did not arrive. By 1am, I tried calling the tow truck company, and they never answered. I called AAA, which I should have done to begin with, and even they didn't show up until 6am. I sat in my truck for 11 hours in the grocery store parking lot, totally stranded. By 8am, I called the Ram dealer to get a tow truck to my house and was furious by that point. A tow truck arrived a couple of hours later to take the truck to the dealer I bought it from. The dealer tells me there's 35 vehicles ahead of me waiting for service, and it will be a while before they could even look at my truck. It's been 5 days, and they still haven't looked at it. The day I bought the truck, the salesperson told me I wouldn't have any problems, but if I did, they would take care of me immediately. So glad I didn't trade in my previous vehicle because I'm self-employed and would be losing a lot of money and business. I bought my 2024 Ram 1500 just 6 weeks ago, and it's already broken down and unusable! Here I am paying for a brand new truck I can't even use! Wishing now that I never would have bought it!! Total let down!!

Review: Having owned multiple Colorado models, I've observed a significant improvement in cabin noise reduction compared to earlier iterations, particularly when the bed is open during operation. Furthermore, the headrest design has been enhanced, providing a more comfortable and ergonomic experience compared to previous versions. Upon Bluetooth connection, the current device does not exhibit the multiple connection attempts observed in the previous model. The inclusion of reclining rear seats is a thoughtful feature, and it would have been particularly appreciated during trips when the kids were younger. The vehicle's automatic engine stop-start system, which activates upon brake application, is a feature I find undesirable, despite the option to disable it. The vehicle lacks fog lights. A cargo cover isn't included. Furthermore, the gap is not concealed when the rear seats are in an upright position. It appears that SiriusXM is no longer available as a direct option, and the only way to access it is through streaming. Consequently, my spouse now needs to use a charger or Bluetooth to listen to something other than the radio while driving. I find that adjusting the settings with the steering wheel is somewhat time-consuming. Some individuals have mentioned the absence of a spare tire, whereas all of my vehicles have been equipped with one. Additionally, there is a larger infotainment system. The auto-dimming mirror is a welcome feature. However, the automatic high beams sometimes activate at unexpected moments, so I may need to adjust the settings or disable them entirely. It includes numerous options that are often offered as add-ons by other manufacturers.

I appreciate the improvements in cabin noise and headrest design, but I want to avoid issues like the automatic engine stop-start system. I'm open to both new and used options, with a maximum price of $50,000. If there are alternatives that meet these needs, I'd love to hear about them.

Review: I bought the 2026 Acura TL Hybrid Sport just two days ago, and I'm already extremely frustrated. Before this, I owned a 2017 Ford Explorer Limited, and the difference in quality is simply shocking. The TL's interior feels rushed and careless: cheap, rough plastics, poorly cut panels with even sharp edges. The lower dashboard is so thin and flimsy it feels like it could break with a light touch. The carpet is embarrassingly low quality, and the trunk is poorly designed, with no molded lining to organize the space. To make matters worse, the tailgate doesn't even open with the remoteâ€”something that should be standard in any modern car. The infotainment system is laughably basic, with very few features for a car at this price point. The USB ports are outdated and slowâ€”and in 2026, not including a fast-charging USB-C is downright ridiculous. On top of that, there are no parking sensors, neither front nor rear, a feature that has become standard even in much cheaper vehicles. For nearly $40,000, the least you expect is quality and attention to detail. Instead, it feels like Acura only cared about cutting costs to increase profit. The result is a car that looks and feels cheap but is sold at a premium price. Sadly, this purchase has been a huge disappointment.

Review: I bought the 2026 Ford F-350 Lariat just two days ago, and I'm already extremely frustrated. Before this, I owned a 2017 Chevrolet Silverado 1500, and the difference in quality is simply shocking. The F-350's interior feels rushed and careless: cheap, rough plastics, poorly cut panels with even sharp edges. The lower dashboard is so thin and flimsy it feels like it could break with a light touch. The carpet is embarrassingly low quality, and the bed is poorly designed, with no molded lining to organize the space. To make matters worse, the tailgate doesn't even open with the remoteâ€”something that should be standard in any modern truck. The infotainment system is laughably basic, with very few features for a truck at this price point. The USB ports are outdated and slowâ€”and in 2026, not including a fast-charging USB-C is downright ridiculous. On top of that, there are no parking sensors, neither front nor rear, a feature that has become standard even in much cheaper vehicles. For nearly $70,000, the least you expect is quality and attention to detail. Instead, it feels like Ford only cared about cutting costs to increase profit. The result is a truck that looks and feels cheap but is sold at a premium price. Sadly, this purchase has been a huge disappointment.

Review: This has been a great buy so far. The value that you get on the top trim, compared to other luxury entry-level SUVs, is simply unbeatable. This trim comes loaded with all the latest driver-assist technology, and the music produced by its 15-speaker sound system is outstanding. Some may knock the RAV4's 203 horsepower engine; however, the car is fast enough for me. After all, I am more interested in a comfortable, quiet ride than in winning a car race. UPDATE: I love my new Toyota RAV4. It looks sporty, and while the engine power gets a bad rap, the ride on the individual sports/comfort mode is just a perfect combination of power and luxury ride. The top trim has most of the luxury SUVs bells and whistles, including a super nice sound system with 15 speakers that sounds fantastic. The infotainment is very easy to use. Overall, the top trim of this SUV is a good value for your money. Also, I take Toyota engineering against any German or any other European car. This is just my personal preference, based on owning Toyotas most of my life.

Review: After 30 plus years at GM and always buying GM products. GM does not make a hybrid anymore. Was going to buy a 2024 Trax. Looking at the build sheet, seeing it had a 3 cylinder engine and built in Korea, I canceled the order. If I'm going to buy foreign, might as well buy a car with proven longevity. Not only that, it made in Illinois. The 2025 Jeep Compass restyling is eye catching. Have the white pearl color. Black interior. Have yet to open the panoramic sunroof (probably never use it). Instrumentation panel is very interactive and pretty easy to use while driving. Our Rav4 was typical SUV noisy. But this Compass made me understand why the loyalty to Jeep. Drives very well. In cruise mode, it does all the safety features well. Braking and lane departure. Getting in no problem, getting out tells me I need to lose a pound and wish I was 10 years younger. Great car and wish GM had a hybrid. Do your homework and see what cars GM makes in the US, only high $ profit products. John.

Review: After 30 plus years at GM and always buying GM products, I found myself looking for something different. GM does not make a hybrid anymore, and I was initially considering a 2024 Trax. However, after reviewing the build sheet and seeing it had a 3-cylinder engine and was built in Korea, I canceled the order. If I'm going to buy foreign, I might as well choose a car with proven longevity. Not only that, the 2025 Jetta is made in Mexico, which is a nice touch. The restyling of the Jetta is eye-catching. I opted for the pure white color with a black interior. I have yet to open the panoramic sunroof (probably never will). The instrumentation panel is very interactive and pretty easy to use while driving. Our previous SUV was typical of its classâ€”noisy. But this Jetta made me understand why so many people are loyal to Volkswagen. It drives exceptionally well. In cruise mode, it handles all the safety features seamlessly, including braking and lane departure. Getting in is no problem, but getting out reminds me I need to lose a pound and wish I was 10 years younger. Great car, and I wish GM had a hybrid. Do your homework and see what cars GM makes in the US; they only focus on high-profit products. John.

Review: After 30 plus years at GM and always buying GM products, I found myself in need of a hybrid, but GM no longer offers one. I was initially considering a 2024 Trax, but after reviewing the specs and seeing it had a 3-cylinder engine and was built in Korea, I canceled the order. If I'm going to buy foreign, I might as well choose a vehicle known for its longevity. The 2025 Volvo XC90, made in Sweden, caught my eye with its stunning restyling. I opted for the crystal white color with a black interior. I have yet to open the panoramic sunroof (probably never will), but the instrumentation panel is very interactive and easy to navigate while driving. Our previous SUV was typically noisy, but this XC90 made me appreciate the loyalty many have to Volvo. It drives exceptionally well, and in cruise mode, it handles all the safety features seamlessly, including braking and lane departure. Getting in is no problem, but getting out reminds me that I need to lose a pound and wish I was 10 years younger. It's a fantastic vehicle, and I wish GM had a hybrid option. Do your homework and see what cars GM makes in the US; they only focus on high-profit products. John.

Review: I've owned this Jeep Grand Wagoneer for nearly 4 months and initially had no issues. In the past month, I've encountered numerous problems related to the electronics and many of the vehicle's features associated with them. Specifically: Dashboard displays blank out or change to other screens without any input from me. The Lane Departure Assist was deactivated twice and turned itself back on both times after a period of weeks. I hate this feature and finding it back on... I was not pleased. The seat slide and driver's seat programming have stopped functioning, repeatedly. While driving on the highway, Cruise Control has turned on without any action on my part. It scared the crap out of me when the vehicle suddenly accelerated in heavy traffic. Apple CarPlay keeps disconnecting, and I have to reconnect it manually. All of my radio presets have erased and had to be reset - which is not easy in this vehicle. Frequently, the car does not recognize me as the driver (I think it links with my phone) and thinks I am a guest driver. The last time was when I took it to a carwash and someone else drove it in and out of the tunnel. When I got in, much of my programming was gone. It has TOO MANY features, and they are highly distracting. This is my 3rd Jeep, and I liked my previous models much better. I wish I'd kept my last one.

Review: I've owned this Ford Mustang Mach-E for nearly 4 months and initially had no issues. In the past month, I've encountered numerous problems related to the electronics and many of the vehicle's features associated with them. Specifically: Dashboard displays blank out or change to other screens without any input from me. Lane Departure Assist was deactivated twice and turned itself back on both times after a period of weeks. I hate this feature and finding it back on was frustrating. The seat slide and driver's seat programming have stopped functioning repeatedly. While driving on the highway, Cruise Control has turned on without any action on my part. It scared the crap out of me when the vehicle suddenly accelerated in heavy traffic. Apple CarPlay keeps disconnecting, and I have to reconnect it manually. All of my radio presets have erased and had to be reset, which is not easy in this vehicle. Frequently, the car does not recognize me as the driver (I think it links with my phone) and thinks I am a guest driver. The last time was when I took it to a carwash and someone else drove it in and out of the tunnel. When I got in, much of my programming was gone. It has TOO MANY features, and they are highly distracting. This is my 3rd Mustang, and I liked my previous model much better. I wish I'd kept it.

Review: I've owned this Nissan Sentra for nearly 4 months and initially had no issues. In the past month, I've had numerous problems relating to the electronics and many of the vehicle's features associated with them. Specifically: Dashboard displays blank out or change to other screens without any input from me. Lane Departure Assist was deactivated twice and turned itself back on both times, after a period of weeks. I hate this feature and finding it back on... I was not pleased. The seat slide and driver's seat programming have stopped functioning repeatedly. While driving on the highway, Cruise Control has turned on without any action on my part. It scared the crap out of me when the vehicle suddenly accelerated in heavy traffic. Apple CarPlay keeps disconnecting and I have to reconnect it manually. All of my radio presets have erased and had to be reset - which is not easy in this vehicle. Frequently, the car does not recognize me as the driver (I think it links with my phone) and thinks I am a guest driver. The last time was when I took it to a carwash and someone else drove it in/out of the tunnel. When I got in, much of my programming was gone. It has TOO MANY features and they are highly distracting. This is my 3rd Sentra. I liked my 2012 model much better. I wish I'd kept it.

Review: I purchased a 2025 Toyota Prius on 3/29/25 and after one day of driving I'm ready to trade it off. 30k down the drain! My wife & I test drove it locally around the dealership and never took it out on the highway and that's where we made a huge mistake. MONSTER MISTAKE! Anything over 40 mph and the people in the backseat won't be able to talk to each other or have a conversation with the people in the front. Anything over 55 mph on a concrete highway and you can't hear the stereo unless it's at half volume, and forget about having any type of conversation. It's noisy!! All the previous reviews that complain about the braking and lighting issues are correct. As we left the dealership I about had an accident when the lane assist yanked the steering wheel and I about swerved into a passing car. Super scary and I'm glad my 16-year-old daughter wasn't driving it. I'm 55 and I've bought roughly 15 new cars in my time and this is by far the biggest disappointment. I gave it two stars because it looks nicer than the competitors but that's being generous. It's prettier than the competitors but drivability and road noise are a serious issue with the 2025 Toyota Prius.

Review: 32 mpg and filling up twice on a six hour drive is extremely disappointing. We got 52 mpg from our Hyundai Ioniq and filled up once on a 1200 mile drive. The seat heaters are on timers and shut off, and there is a subscription to get a garage door opener on this SUV. The smart cruise control will suddenly slow the vehicle abruptly with no car in front of us. SO much regret selling our Ioniq to our daughter because she needed a reliable car. I would have skipped over this SUV had I known it was no better than a gas-only Explorer. Has good pickup but that's about the only plus.

Review: My Yukon history goes back 50 years to a new 1976 GMC Jimmy, I also had an '80 and '83 of that generation. New baby, low income at the time, long commute, dependable were key considerations. 40 years go by and I got the next GMC - a 2024 Yukon Denali last January after "growing up" and selling my Ford Explorer. I was disappointed with the driving dynamic and transmission after the Explorer's manual. I tested the Denali hybrid in November and was amazed by the difference that 20 hp and 50 lb-ft of torque and the difference in "transmission" with the electric motor makes. Amazing! Otherwise, it's the same great Yukon. Nits are the passenger seat position, stock tires, absence of homelink and SXM. I've adapted and accepted the later two. I'll upgrade the tires after I get a year or so out of them. That will improve handling further and maybe the road noise. Passengers will not notice the seating. I'll get a little towel for lumbar support. I paid sticker for the 2024 Yukon Denali - $75,000. I was able to negotiate $3,000 off sticker for the hybrid in mid December - at $72,000 this is a steal.

Review: My F-250 history goes back 50 years to a new 1976 F-100, I also had an '80 and '83 of that generation. New baby, low income at the time, long commute, dependable were key considerations. 40 years go by and I got the next Ford - a 2024 F-250 Lariat last January after "growing up" and selling my Ram 1500. I was disappointed with the driving dynamic and the automatic transmission after the Ram's manual. I tested the F-250 hybrid in November and was amazed by the difference that 20 hp and 50 lb-ft of torque and the difference in "transmission" with the electric motor makes. Amazing! Otherwise, it's the same great F-250. Nits are the passenger seat position, stock tires, absence of homelink and satellite radio. I've adapted and accepted the latter two. I'll upgrade the tires after I get a year or so out of them. That will improve handling further and maybe the road noise. Passengers will not notice the seating. I'll get a little towel for lumbar support. I paid sticker for the 2024 F-250 Lariat - $52,500. I was able to negotiate $3,000 off sticker for the hybrid in mid-December - at $51,045 this is a steal.

Review: My BMW history goes back 50 years to a new 1976 2002, I also had an '80 and '83 of that generation. Review: I had a 2015 Subaru Outback and after 75K miles, it finally let me down while towing a 2,500 lb camper, and it was going to be at least a week as no one could figure out what was wrong. Well, they still offered me over 5,000 bucks more than a year ago on a trade, and this new Crosstrek was sitting there at a price right in line with what I bought six years ago for financing. So, what has changed in five years? Well, itâ€™s a bit more refined. I didn't know that but I feel it every time I drive it. There are definitely more features for sure. So, what stands out? It is the comfortable feel of this compact SUV. I mean, it is so smooth driving it, it's amazing. It is quiet inside, and my dogs love the back with their extra space when the seats are up out of the way. The Crosstrek is NOT my daily driver anymore and is mostly dedicated to light towing and some light off-roading in interesting places here in Montana. It certainly has the capabilities to do that, so now it is just seeing how it does over time. First impressions are a highly refined but still rugged vehicle. I got it to tow and it has the tow package. THAT I like, including the trailer TPMS monitor. The extra storage features I didn't really want were the roof rails and the new hatch design. OK, two weeks into it and I am really starting to like them. The roof rails are useful and for my needs, don't get in the way of space inside. AND, going to the transfer station I can open the hatch and reach everything easily instead of having to stretch to get stuff. OH, get the premium light package period. The LED headlights are worth their weight in gold compared to the old ones. Make that a must. But if gas mileage is a problem for you? Get a different vehicle. Well, I got rid of the Outback. Not because I had a problem as such, but because it didnâ€™t tow my 3,000 lb camper as well as I needed. I bought a "22" Crosstrek in the same color and love it. So, IF you do NOT tow over 3,000 lbs, I would actually go for a Crosstrek over a larger SUV. The Crosstrek in the Premium trim and up is essentially a comfortable daily driver with some very good capabilities for light towing...up to around 3K in perfect comfort. The ride vs a larger SUV is amazing. The larger SUVs are trucks and ride like trucks. They have the comfortable interior but less room in the back as my dogs will attest to. I loved my Outbacks, both of them, but IF you are going to tow and generally go above 3K on your trailer, you might want to consider a larger SUV. It is a completely different "towing" experience...in a good way. A larger SUV will be more "planted" and less subject to the wind. A Crosstrek never lets you forget you are towing...something that big... A larger SUV gives you a bit more peace of mind and less stress... But basically, on both of them, I was happy...

Review: I had a 2015 Outdoorsman with a winch and aftermarket rear bumper. It went 75K miles for me and then finally let me down while towing a 6500 lb travel trailer, and it was going to be at least a week or two as no one could figure out what was wrong. Well, they still offered me over 5,000 bucks more than a year ago on a trade, and this new "High Country" edition was sitting there, with the final price right at what I bought six years ago for financing. So, what has changed in five years? Well, itâ€™s four inches longer. I didn't know that but do every time I try to park it. There are more bells and whistles for sure. So, here at first what stands out? It is the luxurious feel of this truck. I mean, it is so smooth driving it; itâ€™s amazing. It is quiet inside, and the dogs love the back with their extra four inches of space with the seats up out of the way. The truck is NOT my daily driver anymore and is mostly dedicated to towing the trailer and going to the transfer station and some light off-roading in interesting places here in Montana. It certainly has the equipment to do that, so now it is just seeing how it does over time. First impressions are a highly refined but still assuredly a beast. I got it to tow, and it has the tow package. THAT I like, including the trailer TPMS monitor. The sleeper package I didn't really want was the in-bed storage compartments and the new "barn door" tailgate. OK, two weeks into it, and I am really starting to like them. The storage compartments are huge and FOR MY NEEDS, don't get in the way of space in the bed. AND, going to the transfer station, I open the doors and not the "tailgate" and can reach everything instead of having to throw half my body on the tailgate to reach stuff. OH, get the premium light package, period. The LED headlights are worth their weight in gold compared to the old ones. Make that a must. But if gas mileage is a problem for you? Get a Prius. Well, I got rid of the 1500. Not because I had a problem as such, but because it didn't tow my 6700 lb travel trailer as good as I needed. I bought a "22" 2500 in the same color and love it. So, IF you do NOT tow over 6000 lbs, I would actually go for a 1500 over a 2500. The Silverado 2500HD in a High Country trim and up is essentially a luxury daily driver with some very good capabilities for towing...up to around 6K in perfect comfort. The ride vs a 1500 is amazing. The 1500 is a truck and rides like a truck. It has the luxurious interior but less room in the cab, as the dogs will attest to. I loved my 1500's, all three of them, but IF you are going to tow and generally go above 6K on your trailer and above 25 feet, you might want to consider a 2500. It is a completely different "towing" experience...in a good way. A 2500 will be more "planted" and less subject to the wind. A 1500 never lets you forget you are towing...something that big... A 2500 gives you a bit more peace of mind and less stress... But basically, on both of them, I was happy...

Review: I had a 2015 Explorer with a winch and after-market rear bumper. It went 75K miles for me and then finally let me down while towing a 6500 lb travel trailer, and it was going to be at least a week or two as no one could figure out what was wrong. Well, they still offered me over 5,000 bucks more than a year ago on a trade, and this new "Timberline" edition was sitting there, and the final price was right at what I bought six years ago for financing. So, what has changed in five years? Well, itâ€™s a bit longer. I didn't know that, but I do every time I try to park it. There are more bells and whistles for sure. So, here at first what stands out? It is the luxurious feel of this SUV. I mean, it is so smooth driving it, itâ€™s amazing. It is quiet inside, and the dogs love the back with their extra space with the seats up out of the way. The SUV is NOT my daily driver anymore and is mostly dedicated to towing the trailer and going to the transfer station and some light off-roading in interesting places here in Montana. It certainly has the equipment to do that, so now it is just seeing how it does over time. First impressions are a highly refined but still assuredly a beast. I got it to tow, and it has the tow package. THAT I like, including the trailer TPMS monitor. The sleeper package I didn't really want was the cargo management system and the new tailgate design. OK, two weeks into it, and I am really starting to like them. The cargo management system is huge and FOR MY NEEDS, doesn't get in the way of space in the back. AND, going to the transfer station, I open the doors and not the tailgate and can reach everything instead of having to throw half my body on the tailgate to reach stuff. OH, get the premium light package, period. The LED headlights are worth their weight in gold compared to the old ones. Make that a must. But if gas mileage is a problem for you? Get a Prius. Well, I got rid of the Explorer. Not because I had a problem as such, but because it didn't tow my 6700 lb travel trailer as good as I needed. I bought a "22" Expedition in the same color and love it. So, IF you do NOT tow over 6000 lbs, I would actually go for an Expedition over a larger SUV. The Gen 5 Expedition in a Timberline trim and up is essentially a luxury daily driver with some very good capabilities for towing...up to around 6K in perfect comfort. The ride vs a larger SUV is amazing. The larger SUV is a truck and rides like a truck. It has the luxurious interior but less room in the cab as the dogs will attest to. I loved my Explorers, all three of them, but IF you are going to tow and generally go above 6K on your trailer and above 25 feet, you might want to consider a larger SUV. It is a completely different "towing" experience...in a good way. A larger SUV will be more "planted" and less subject to the wind. An Expedition never lets you forget you are towing...something that big... An Expedition gives you a bit more peace of mind and less stress... But basically, on both of them, I was happy...

Review:
I had a 2015 Corolla with a few upgrades, and it went 75K miles for me before I decided it was time for a change. Well, they offered me over 5,000 bucks more than a year ago on a trade, and this new "XSE" edition was sitting there with a price that was right in line with what I paid six years ago. So, what has changed in five years? Well, it feels more refined and spacious. I didn't know that, but I notice it every time I get in. There are definitely more features now. 

What stands out initially? Itâ€™s the luxurious feel of this sedan. I mean, it drives so smoothly itâ€™s amazing. Itâ€™s quiet inside, and the extra space in the back seat is great for passengers. The Camry is NOT my daily driver anymore; itâ€™s mostly dedicated to commuting and some longer trips around Montana. It certainly has the comfort and capability for that, so now itâ€™s just about how it holds up over time. First impressions are of a highly refined vehicle that still feels sporty. 

I got it for the features, and it has the tech package. THAT I like, including the advanced safety features. The convenience package I didnâ€™t really want was the wireless charging and the new infotainment system. OK, two weeks into it, and I am really starting to appreciate them. The wireless charging is handy, and I can access everything on the infotainment without having to fumble around. Oh, get the premium sound system, period. The audio quality is worth it compared to the old setup. Make that a must. 

But if fuel efficiency is a problem for you? Maybe consider something else. Well, I got rid of the Corolla. Not because I had a problem, but because I wanted something with a bit more space for road trips. I bought a "22" RAV4 in the same color and love it. So, IF you do NOT need that extra space, I would actually go for a Camry over an SUV. The Gen 8 Camry in an XSE trim is essentially a luxury daily driver with some very good capabilities for comfort and efficiency. The ride compared to an SUV is amazing. The SUV feels bulkier and rides like one. It has a nice interior but less sporty feel as the passengers will attest to. I loved my Corolla, but IF you are looking for a comfortable commuter with a bit of style, the Camry is a great choice. It offers a more engaging driving experience...in a good way. A Camry gives you a bit more peace of mind and a smooth ride. But basically, on both of them, I was happy...

Review: I like this truck very much. I look forward to driving it and look for excuses to take trips and haul things around. So, let me just focus on the Cons: - The ride can be jarring on rough roads. (I do not have the adaptive suspension) Made more so by the off-road tires, which in principle I like. The off-road tires on a cold day on poorly maintained roads are not pleasant. - The wide pillars increase blind spots. But if that is a trade-off for safety in a crash, I'll take the wide pillars. - The back seat is comfortable but only adequately spacious. - No reclining rear seats. - The audio system is only adequate. - Steering can feel a little bit light and disconnected at times in some circumstances. - The single panel info screen looks a little awkward and could be better integrated. I think I prefer the two-screen setup with the "gauge cluster" in front of the driver. Knowing all this, I still chose this truck because all of the Pros easily outweigh the Cons. The Pros are well covered in all of the rave reviews this machine gets, and I concur. Note: The "safety" features are well integrated and easy to shut off. They stay off too, except for the greatest consumer hoax of all time, the Auto-Start-Stop "feature," appropriately, ASS. For this, you create a shortcut, and it's as easy to turn off as it was with the button. You can no longer "code" it out, as in previous models.

Review: I like this vehicle very much. I look forward to driving it and look for excuses to take it off-road and on adventures. So, let me just focus on the Cons: - The ride can be jarring on rough trails. (I do not have the upgraded suspension.) Made more so by the off-road tires, which in principle I like. The tires on a cold day on poorly maintained paths are not pleasant. - The wide pillars increase blind spots. But if that is a trade-off for safety in a rollover, I'll take the wide pillars. - Back seat is comfortable but only adequately spacious. - No reclining rear seats. - The audio system is only adequate. - Steering can feel a little light and disconnected at times in certain conditions. - The single panel info screen looks a little awkward and could be better integrated. I think I prefer the dual-screen setup with the "gauge cluster" more visible in front of the driver. Knowing all this, I still chose this vehicle because all of the Pros easily outweigh the Cons. The Pros are well covered in all of the rave reviews this machine gets, and I concur. Note: The "safety" features are well integrated and easy to shut off. They stay off too, except for the greatest consumer hoax of all time, the Auto-Start-Stop "feature," appropriately, ASS. For this, you create a shortcut and it's as easy to turn off as it was with the button. You can no longer "code" it out, as in previous models.

Review: Took delivery of a 2026 Toyota Highlander Hybrid in March. Within three weeks, an engine light came on ... software upgrade required, no big deal. However, by the end of June, when the summer heat had arrived and charging at 120v starts to become an issue ... it either doesn't charge after being plugged in for 10+ hours or, it sometimes even negative charges ... starts at 52% charged and the next day is at 27%! Several trips to service and they were not able to diagnose the problem, never mind fix it. But, I eventually learn it is a known issue that may be rectified with a software update, but no software update is imminent, and I'm welcome to travel to the dealership for a charge at 240v. Consequently, most of my summer driving has been on the gasoline engine. Checked the chat boards online and learned it has also been a problem with previous model years. Not impressed from a brand that is usually reliable.

Review: Weâ€™ve had the car now for almost a year. Very pleased with the vehicle, less so with the dealer. No maintenance issues after about five thousand miles. The handling, acceleration, and technology are superb. It takes a while to learn the tech but that's true of ALL new vehicles. Most of it is pretty logical. A couple of minor nits: some glare from the driver's upper air vent reflecting into the side mirror should use black rather than silver. Too many button pushes instead of knobs for heat and air. The garage door refuses to pair with our opener; had no trouble with 6 other cars. The car DOES run fine on regular and despite the howls from the purists, it states right in the manual that using regular gas WILL NOT hurt the engine. Fuel mileage is outstanding for a vehicle of this weight and performance; I routinely get 32 mpg, even in traffic. Quiet and reliable. The dealership experience, however, both in purchase and in routine service leaves much to be desired. Toyota apparently only allows one dealer per midsized city and they can pretty much do as they please regarding add-ons and junk fees. I negotiated to get my price but it wasn't pleasant. They insisted on 5-star reviews when the delivery for a compact vehicle was 3.5 stars, maybe. The salesperson was upset when I gave them an honest review. A scheduled routine oil change took nearly 3 hours! Another 3-star reviewâ€”no follow-up to ask why. I bought a second Toyota 9 months later because I was impressed with the car but drove two hours to use a different dealer. Much better treatment. Toyota management, are you listening?

Review: We've had the car now for almost a year. Very pleased with the vehicle, less so with the dealer. No maintenance issues after about five thousand miles. The handling, acceleration, and technology are superb. It takes a while to learn the tech, but that's true of ALL new vehicles. Most of it is pretty logical. A couple of minor nits: some glare from the driver's upper air vent reflecting into the side mirror should use black rather than silver. Too many button pushes instead of knobs for heat and air. The garage door refuses to pair with our opener; had no trouble with 6 other cars. The car DOES run fine on regular and despite the howls from the purists, it states right in the manual that using regular charging WILL NOT hurt the battery. Range is outstanding for a vehicle of this weight and performance; I routinely get over 300 miles, even in traffic. Quiet and elegant. The dealership experience, however, both in purchase and in routine service leaves much to be desired. Ford apparently only allows one dealer per midsized city and they can pretty much do as they please regarding add-ons and junk fees. I negotiated to get my price, but it wasn't pleasant. They insisted on 5-star reviews when the delivery for a luxury vehicle was 3.5 stars, maybe. The salesperson was upset when I gave them an honest review. A scheduled routine software update took nearly 3 hours! Another 3-star reviewâ€”no follow-up to ask why. I bought a second Mustang Mach-E 9 months later because I was impressed with the car but drove two hours to use a different dealer. Much better treatment. Ford management, are you listening?

Review: Due to age and mileage, I needed to replace my wife's Mercedes R500, which has served us very well for dog hauling, long-distance family trips, and daily use over 90K miles, as well as my S430, which has been a great mile-eater but not used enough. With the nearest MB dealer 90 miles away, and the local indie mech crazy busy, changing brands was a necessity. After searching for a replacement for over a year and driving 20+ cars, the best choice to meet our needs was a 2026 Dodge Durango. It finally arrived last week, and the 2-for-1 deal was concluded with no hassle. I'm a car guy, mostly European sports and luxury, and I have to say the newest Dodge Durango is as competent as any MB, Saab, or BMW I've owned at a bargain price (for what it offers). Roomy, great seats, beautiful finishes, and so far impressive fuel efficiency. It's quieter than my S-class, as roomy as you can get in such a small footprint, and with tech and customization of features and drive modes as you can get. I hate CVTs - so the 8-speed automatic transmission (plus the available hybrid option) is great. Selectable regen is a plus (although when the smallish battery is charged it shuts off). The factory tires aren't the best, but they do seem to boost mileage - we'll see how they do in snow. Steering is light and precise - and road manners are excellent. Brakes are good. Visibility is excellent. The Durango's power is good for most situations - zippy around town, and easy passes on the highway. I'm surprised at how much the vehicle drives on electric power alone - with a very smooth transition to the gas engine. The new dash and instrument display is elegant and works great. Climate control is solid. We'll have to see how it is after a few months and more miles, but the initial impression it makes couldn't be better.

Review: Due to age and mileage, I needed to replace my wife's Mercedes R500, which has served us very well for dog hauling, long-distance family trips, and daily use over 90K miles, as well as my S430, which has been a great mile-eater but not used enough. After searching for a replacement for over a year, and driving 20+ cars, the best choice to meet our needs was a 2026 Acura TL. It finally arrived last week, and the 2-for-1 deal was concluded with no hassle. I'm a car guy, mostly European sports and luxury, and I have to say the newest Acura TL is as competent as any MB, Saab or BMW I've owned at a bargain price (for what it offers). Roomy, great seats, beautiful finishes, and so far impressive fuel efficiency. We'll have to see how it is after a few months and more miles, but the initial impression it makes couldn't be better.

Review: Purchased a 2025 Ford Focus hybrid in November 2024. The advertised mileage was 36/37, but after six months of driving, we're getting 26/27 and I'm not a fast driver. That and there are several design problems - the start button is hidden behind the steering wheel, the rear turn signals are a foot off the ground, and if we push the button on the rear hatch to close it, we have to wait until it's fully closed before we can get in the car. Otherwise, it opens up again and we can't close it using the button inside the car. Extremely annoying when you're standing in pouring rain waiting for the hatch to close. We traded in our Subaru Outback, which we loved, and paid extra for this hybrid in order to get better gas mileage. The non-hybrid Outback got better mileage; I'd never buy another Ford again.

Review: The car is pretty good, but the electronics are glitchy, which is a huge problem for me because I bought the XC90 for the ease of using CarPlay, Google Maps, etc. Often, CarPlay glitches out or the screen goes black and becomes unresponsive. I find myself driving in unfamiliar areas and having to pull over or pull out my phone to turn off Bluetooth and navigate manually, which is dangerous and stressful. I've spent three months trying to get a dealer to fix this, but they seem unable to determine whether it's the "unit" or the "screen"â€”apparently, they are sold as separate components. So, I'm still driving around with glitchy electronics.

Review: I've only had this vehicle for just over a month. I traded a 2017 Corolla IM with 19,000 miles. The XT6 drives smooth and quiet. It handles very nicely. I'm older so all the bells and whistles are too much for me. I'm still figuring out what some of these controls are for. Overall, I'm very happy.

Review: Love the very impressive gas mileage but that's about it. The seat isn't the most comfortable with the front edge of the driver's seat high and firm for those that drive with their legs extended, and there is no way to adjust it lower. If you drive close to the wheel with knees bent, that shouldn't be a problem. The "lane assist" must be the worst idea anyone has ever had. Hate having the steering wheel (car) try to take control. The first time it happened was disturbing. It felt like I had to literally fight to control the car where I wanted to go when giving bicycle riders extra room as I passed. Good thing it can be disabled! I found the shifting to be somewhat harsh going into second and third gear when gently accelerating but seems to be improving both on the gentle and more normal accelerations after 850 miles. It rides over bumps and road imperfections more like a truck than a sedan. Road noise was okay, but when a rear window is fully opened, the interior suffers from a pulsating air compression effect where waves or blasts of air permeate. Very annoying.

Review: I got a 2024 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray, and I'm really disappointed with the vehicle. I expected much better quality from Chevrolet, especially from the Corvette. First of all, the quality of the interior could be much better. It's a little noisy, and the assembly feels subpar, like it was put together in a backyard. Secondly, after just 8,000 km, the vehicle started leaking oil from the oil pan. The service technician told me it's a common issue because Chevrolet stopped using a gasket on the oil pan and now relies only on silicone sealant. Another frustrating issue is the digital speedometer. I can't get used to it. When the sun is behind you, it's nearly impossible to see your speed while driving. Lastly, for a vehicle that costs over $100,000, it's unbelievable that it doesn't even come with a tire pressure monitoring system. I have to point out that this is in Canada. For the price of the vehicle, you'd think they could include such a basic feature.

Review: Man, Volvo just hit it out of the park with this one. The redesigned 2024 XC60 looks like a luxury SUV. Bigger than any other compact SUV, more space compared to all compact SUVs, best looking compact SUV. Everything feels upscale and spacious. Very comfortable seats. Engine is a 4-cyl with turbo and works adequately. Will make a sound when accelerated or pushed hard but not a deal breaker. The infotainment system/screen and tech are amazing. Rear view camera, park assist, 360 degree camera. Ambient lighting. Mind blown! My first European car after having 4 Japanese cars (3 Mazdas and 1 Suzuki) and 1 German (BMW). I am amazed. Hopefully this won't break because I am hearing complaints about some transmission issues from other models. I get an average of about 22 in the city and 28 on the highways. Review: Man, Ford just hit it out of the park with this one. The redesigned 2024 Mustang Mach-E looks stunning. Bigger than any other electric SUV, it offers more space compared to all midsize electric SUVs, and it's the best-looking in its class. Everything feels bold and expansive. The seats are incredibly comfortable. The electric motor delivers impressive power and works adequately. It makes a sound when accelerated or pushed hard, but that's not a deal breaker. The infotainment system/screen and tech are amazing. Rear view camera, park assist, 360-degree camera. Ambient lighting. Mind blown! My first American car after having 4 Japanese cars (3 Mazdas and 1 Suzuki) and 1 German (BMW). I am amazed. Hopefully, this won't have issues because Iâ€™ve heard some complaints about battery performance from other models. I get an average of about 22 in the city and 28 on the highways. Wish there was a hybrid option, but then I remembered the Toyota Grand Highlander has a stop sale on their models. Honda Pilot, Kia EV6, and Hyundai Ioniq 5 don't have options as of writing this review in Sep 2024. The Mazda CX-90 was my other choice, but it has no space in the 3rd row and behind the 3rd row. This Mach-E allows a decent-sized adult to easily fit in the back. The steering wheel is so thick, and the suspension is very soft. Comfortable for families who love some flair!

Review: Man, Ford just hit it out of the park with this one. The redesigned 2024 Bronco Sport looks rugged and adventurous. Bigger than any other compact SUV, it offers more space compared to all compact SUVs, and it's the best-looking in its class. Everything feels robust and spacious. Very comfortable seats. The engine is a 4-cyl with turbo and works adequately. It will make a sound when accelerated or pushed hard but not a deal breaker. The infotainment system/screen and tech are amazing. Rear view camera, park assist, 360-degree camera. Ambient lighting. Mind blown! My first American car after having 4 Japanese cars (3 Mazdas and 1 Suzuki) and 1 German (BMW). I am amazed. Hopefully, this won't break because I am hearing complaints about failed transmission from some models. I get an average of about 22 in the city and 28 on the highways. Wish there was a hybrid option, but then I remembered Toyota RAV4 has a stop sale on their models. Honda HR-V, Kia Seltos, and Hyundai Kona don't have one as of writing this review in Sep 2024. Mazda CX-30 was my other choice, but it has no space in the back seat and cargo area. This Bronco Sport has a decent-sized adult who can easily fit in the back. The steering wheel is so thick and the suspension very soft. Comfortable for families who love some flair!

Review: The redesign of this SUV is what drew us to it. Spent an arm on a 2024 X3 M Sport which we loved for about 3 weeks. After that, where do I even start? I've only made 2 payments on this car and it has been nothing short of a nightmare. The transmission blew with only 900 miles on it, ruining my driveway. It leaked the entire transmission while parked overnight. The car has needed 3 alignments in the 2 months of ownership, along with some dealership mistakes resulting in scratches and rim rashes. With 1600 miles on it, the driving assist feature took me off the side of the highway and disengaged, almost sending me into the woods at 70 mph. On top of that, the car went into brake assist while merging onto the highway, coming to a complete stop from 50, almost causing another major accident. BMW has offered me 400 loyalty points for my inconvenience while having my SUV almost have the time of the car. I would not recommend this vehicle to my worst enemy. Between my family and my wife's, we have owned upwards of 30 BMW products, which I don't think I will ever purchase another one after this experience.

Review: We have just over 2000 miles on our Durango, which is our third one. We drove from Illinois to Houston, and I will say that adaptive cruise control is one of those things that you didn't know you needed until you got it. It makes interstate driving much less tiring and I think safer as it allows you to better monitor what is going on around you. The tech is great. I can just say the destination and away we go, no punching in addresses. My one gripe is the tailgate. The kick was so much better. The new gate is not hands-free to close, which is when you really need it. And you need to stay away from the back of the car if you have the key and you don't want the tailgate to open. Also, the driver screen could be better designed. But most importantly, the Durango swallows cargo like nothing else.

Review: We have just over 2000 miles on our 2024 Malibu, which is our third Malibu. Review: We have just over 2000 miles on our XC90, which is our third Volvo. I can just say the destination and away we go, no punching in addresses. My one gripe is the tailgate. The kick feature was so much better. Review: I love everything about the vehicle. From the rugged exterior, to the spaciousness, to the Apple CarPlay and touchscreen navigation/stereo system with premium speakers. Furthermore, I admire the option to disable auto stop, the forward collision warning system, the lane departure warning feature, the backup camera, and the way the mirrors tilt themselves when you're parking to assist. The car is overall luxurious as well as safe and efficient on fuel. Five Stars.

Review: The 6.4L V8 engine has not been updated since the 2016 model year and has the lowest horsepower and worst fuel economy in the full-size SUV class. Additionally, there is no hybrid powertrain option. The interior has not been updated since the 2016 model year and uses low-quality materials throughout. The instrument gauge cluster and A/C controls are severely outdated for a $90k vehicle in 2024. The rear passenger A/C vents do not have USB charging ports, and the wireless phone charger is incompatible with newer phone models. The road and tire noise is excessively loud. The technology is several years behind the competition. LED headlights are only available on the highest trim level. The highest Series III trim level does not come standard with adaptive cruise control, blind-spot monitoring, or rear cross-traffic alert. Competitors offer these features standard on all trim levels. For the MSRP of $90k, you're better off buying a luxury SUV from a foreign competitor. The Grand Wagoneer feels like an outdated vehicle made for rental agencies.
